great and trusty business in a main danger fail you.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: I would I knew in what particular action to try him.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
None better than to let him fetch off his drum,
which you hear him so confidently undertake to do.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
I, with a troop of Florentines, will suddenly
surprise him; such I will have, whom I am sure he
knows not from the enemy: we will bind and hoodwink
him so, that he shall suppose no other but that he
is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries, when
we bring him to our own tents. Be but your lordship
present at his examination: if he do not, for the
promise of his life and in the highest compulsion of
base fear, offer to betray you and deliver all the
intelligence in his power against you, and that with
the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never
trust my judgment in any thing.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum;
he says he has a stratagem for't: when your
lordship sees the bottom of his success in't, and to
what metal this counterfeit lump of ore will be
melted, if you give him not John Drum's
entertainment, your inclining cannot be removed.
Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
O, for the love of laughter,
hinder not the honour of his design: let him fetch
off his drum in any hand.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
How now, monsieur! this drum sticks sorely in your
disposition.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: A pox on't, let it go; 'tis but a drum.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
'But a drum'! is't 'but a drum'? A drum so lost!
There was excellent command,—to charge in with our
horse upon our own wings, and to rend our own soldiers!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
That was not to be blamed in the command of the
service: it was a disaster of war that Caesar
himself could not have prevented, if he had been
there to command.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success: some
dishonour we had in the loss of that drum; but it is
not to be recovered.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: It might have been recovered.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: It might; but it is not now.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
It is to be recovered: but that the merit of
service is seldom attributed to the true and exact
performer, I would have that drum or another, or
'hic jacet.'

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur: if you
think your mystery in stratagem can bring this
instrument of honour again into his native quarter,
be magnanimous in the enterprise and go on; I will
grace the attempt for a worthy exploit: if you
speed well in it, the duke shall both speak of it.
and extend to you what further becomes his
greatness, even to the utmost syllable of your
worthiness.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: But you must not now slumber in it.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I'll about it this evening: and I will presently
pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my
certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation;
and by midnight look to hear further from me.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: May I be bold to acquaint his grace you are gone about it?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I know not what the success will be, my lord; but
the attempt I vow.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
I know thou'rt valiant; and, to the possibility of
thy soldiership, will subscribe for thee. Farewell.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: I love not many words.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
No more than a fish loves water. Is not this a
strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently seems
to undertake this business, which he knows is not to
be done; damns himself to do and dares better be
damned than to do't?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
You do not know him, my lord, as we do: certain it
is that he will steal himself into a man's favour and
for a week escape a great deal of discoveries; but
when you find him out, you have him ever after.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of
this that so seriously he does address himself unto?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
None in the world; but return with an invention and
clap upon you two or three probable lies: but we
have almost embossed him; you shall see his fall
to-night; for indeed he is not for your lordship's respect.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we case
him. He was first smoked by the old lord Lafeu:
when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what a
sprat you shall find him; which you shall see this
very night.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: I must go look my twigs: he shall be caught.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Your brother he shall go along with me.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: As't please your lordship: I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Now will I lead you to the house, and show you
The lass I spoke of.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: But you say she's honest.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
That's all the fault: I spoke with her but once
And found her wondrous cold; but I sent to her,
By this same coxcomb that we have i' the wind,
Tokens and letters which she did re-send;
And this is all I have done. She's a fair creature:
Will you go see her?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: With all my heart, my lord.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
If you misdoubt me that I am not she,
I know not how I shall assure you further,
But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
Though my estate be fallen, I was well born,
Nothing acquainted with these businesses;
And would not put my reputation now
In any staining act.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
Nor would I wish you.
First, give me trust, the count he is my husband,
And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken
Is so from word to word; and then you cannot,
By the good aid that I of you shall borrow,
Err in bestowing it.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
I should believe you:
For you have show'd me that which well approves
You're great in fortune.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
Take this purse of gold,
And let me buy your friendly help thus far,
Which I will over-pay and pay again
When I have found it. The count he wooes your daughter,
Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty,
Resolved to carry her: let her in fine consent,
As we'll direct her how 'tis best to bear it.
Now his important blood will nought deny
That she'll demand: a ring the county wears,
That downward hath succeeded in his house
From son to son, some four or five descents
Since the first father wore it: this ring he holds
In most rich choice; yet in his idle fire,
To buy his will, it would not seem too dear,
Howe'er repented after.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
Now I see
The bottom of your purpose.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
You see it lawful, then: it is no more,
But that your daughter, ere she seems as won,
Desires this ring; appoints him an encounter;
In fine, delivers me to fill the time,
Herself most chastely absent: after this,
To marry her, I'll add three thousand crowns
To what is passed already.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
I have yielded:
Instruct my daughter how she shall persever,
That time and place with this deceit so lawful
May prove coherent. Every night he comes
With musics of all sorts and songs composed
To her unworthiness: it nothing steads us
To chide him from our eaves; for he persists
As if his life lay on't.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
Why then to-night
Let us assay our plot; which, if it speed,
Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed
And lawful meaning in a lawful act,
Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact:
But let's about it.

p.stage: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner.
When you sally upon him, speak what terrible
language you will: though you understand it not
yourselves, no matter; for we must not seem to
understand him, unless some one among us whom we
must produce for an interpreter.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: No, sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: E'en such as you speak to me.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
He must think us some band of strangers i' the
adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of
all neighbouring languages; therefore we must every
one be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we
speak one to another; so we seem to know, is to
know straight our purpose: choughs' language,
gabble enough, and good enough. As for you,
interpreter, you must seem very politic. But couch,
ho! here he comes, to beguile two hours in a sleep,
and then to return and swear the lies he forges.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Ten o'clock: within these three hours 'twill be
time enough to go home. What shall I say I have
done? It must be a very plausive invention that
carries it: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces
have of late knocked too often at my door. I find
my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the
fear of Mars before it and of his creatures, not
daring the reports of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue
was guilty of.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
What the devil should move me to undertake the
recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the
impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I
must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in
exploit: yet slight ones will not carry it; they
will say, 'Came you off with so little?' and great
ones I dare not give. Wherefore, what's the
instance? Tongue, I must put you into a
butter-woman's mouth and buy myself another of
Bajazet's mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
Is it possible he should know what he is, and be
that he is?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I would the cutting of my garments would serve the
turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: We cannot afford you so.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in
stratagem.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: 'Twould not do.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Hardly serve.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Though I swore I leaped from the window of the citadel.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: How deep?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Thirty fathom.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I would I had any drum of the enemy's: I would swear
I recovered it.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: You shall hear one anon.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: A drum now of the enemy's,—

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villiando par corbo, cargo.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: O, ransom, ransom! do not hide mine eyes.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I know you are the Muskos' regiment:
And I shall lose my life for want of language;
If there be here German, or Dane, low Dutch,
Italian, or French, let him speak to me; I'll
Discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
Boskos vauvado: I understand thee, and can speak
thy tongue. Kerely bonto, sir, betake thee to thy
faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: O!

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
The general is content to spare thee yet;
And, hoodwink'd as thou art, will lead thee on
To gather from thee: haply thou mayst inform
Something to save thy life.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
O, let me live!
And all the secrets of our camp I'll show,
Their force, their purposes; nay, I'll speak that
Which you will wonder at.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: But wilt thou faithfully?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: If I do not, damn me.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
Acordo linta.
Come on; thou art granted space.

p.stage: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
Go, tell the Count Rousillon, and my brother,
We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled
Till we do hear from them.

sp.speaker: Second Soldier
sp.p: Captain, I will.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
A' will betray us all unto ourselves:
Inform on that.

sp.speaker: Second Soldier
sp.p: So I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Till then I'll keep him dark and safely lock'd.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: No, my good lord, Diana.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Titled goddess;
And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul,
In your fine frame hath love no quality?
If quick fire of youth light not your mind,
You are no maiden, but a monument:
When you are dead, you should be such a one
As you are now, for you are cold and stem;
And now you should be as your mother was
When your sweet self was got.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: She then was honest.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: So should you be.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
No:
My mother did but duty; such, my lord,
As you owe to your wife.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
No more o' that;
I prithee, do not strive against my vows:
I was compell'd to her; but I love thee
By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever
Do thee all rights of service.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
Ay, so you serve us
Till we serve you; but when you have our roses,
You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves
And mock us with our bareness.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: How have I sworn!

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth,
But the plain single vow that is vow'd true.
What is not holy, that we swear not by,
But take the High'st to witness: then, pray you, tell me,
If I should swear by God's great attributes,
I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths,
When I did love you ill? This has no holding,
To swear by him whom I protest to love,
That I will work against him: therefore your oaths
Are words and poor conditions, but unseal'd,
At least in my opinion.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Change it, change it;
Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy;
And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts
That you do charge men with. Stand no more off,
But give thyself unto my sick desires,
Who then recover: say thou art mine, and ever
My love as it begins shall so persever.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
I see that men make ropes in such a scarre
That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
I'll lend it thee, my dear; but have no power
To give it from me.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: Will you not, my lord?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
It is an honour 'longing to our house,
Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world
In me to lose.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
Mine honour's such a ring:
My chastity's the jewel of our house,
Bequeathed down from many ancestors;
Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world
In me to lose: thus your own proper wisdom
Brings in the champion Honour on my part,
Against your vain assault.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Here, take my ring:
My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine,
And I'll be bid by thee.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window:
I'll order take my mother shall not hear.
Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed,
Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me:
My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them
When back again this ring shall be deliver'd:
And on your finger in the night I'll put
Another ring, that what in time proceeds
May token to the future our past deeds.
Adieu, till then; then, fail not. You have won
A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
For which live long to thank both heaven and me!
You may so in the end.
My mother told me just how he would woo,
As if she sat in 's heart; she says all men
Have the like oaths: he had sworn to marry me
When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid,
Marry that will, I live and die a maid:
Only in this disguise I think't no sin
To cozen him that would unjustly win.

p.stage: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: You have not given him his mother's letter?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
I have delivered it an hour since: there is
something in't that stings his nature; for on the
reading it he changed almost into another man.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking
off so good a wife and so sweet a lady.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
Especially he hath incurred the everlasting
displeasure of the king, who had even tuned his
bounty to sing happiness to him. I will tell you a
thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am the
grave of it.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in
Florence, of a most chaste renown; and this night he
fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour: he hath
given her his monumental ring, and thinks himself
made in the unchaste composition.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
Now, God delay our rebellion! as we are ourselves,
what things are we!

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
Merely our own traitors. And as in the common course
of all treasons, we still see them reveal
themselves, till they attain to their abhorred ends,
so he that in this action contrives against his own
nobility, in his proper stream o'erflows himself.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
Is it not meant damnable in us, to be trumpeters of
our unlawful intents? We shall not then have his
company to-night?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
That approaches apace; I would gladly have him see
his company anatomized, that he might take a measure
of his own judgments, wherein so curiously he had
set this counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
We will not meddle with him till he come; for his
presence must be the whip of the other.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: In the mean time, what hear you of these wars?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: I hear there is an overture of peace.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
What will Count Rousillon do then? will he travel
higher, or return again into France?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogether
of his council.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
Let it be forbid, sir; so should I be a great deal
of his act.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
Sir, his wife some two months since fled from his
house: her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques
le Grand; which holy undertaking with most austere
sanctimony she accomplished; and, there residing the
tenderness of her nature became as a prey to her
grief; in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and
now she sings in heaven.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: How is this justified?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
The stronger part of it by her own letters, which
makes her story true, even to the point of her
death: her death itself, which could not be her
office to say is come, was faithfully confirmed by
the rector of the place.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Hath the count all this intelligence?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from
point, so to the full arming of the verity.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our losses!

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
And how mightily some other times we drown our gain
in tears! The great dignity that his valour hath
here acquired for him shall at home be encountered
with a shame as ample.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and
ill together: our virtues would be proud, if our
faults whipped them not; and our crimes would
despair, if they were not cherished by our virtues.
How now! where's your master?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p:
He met the duke in the street, sir, of whom he hath
taken a solemn leave: his lordship will next
morning for France. The duke hath offered him
letters of commendations to the king.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
They shall be no more than needful there, if they
were more than they can commend.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
They cannot be too sweet for the king's tartness.
Here's his lordship now.
How now, my lord! is't not after midnight?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
I have to-night dispatched sixteen businesses, a
month's length a-piece, by an abstract of success:
I have congied with the duke, done my adieu with his
nearest; buried a wife, mourned for her; writ to my
lady mother I am returning; entertained my convoy;
and between these main parcels of dispatch effected
many nicer needs; the last was the greatest, but
that I have not ended yet.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
If the business be of any difficulty, and this
morning your departure hence, it requires haste of
your lordship.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
I mean, the business is not ended, as fearing to
hear of it hereafter. But shall we have this
dialogue between the fool and the soldier? Come,
bring forth this counterfeit module, he has deceived
me, like a double-meaning prophesier.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
Bring him forth: has sat i' the stocks all night,
poor gallant knave.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
No matter: his heels have deserved it, in usurping
his spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
I have told your lordship already, the stocks carry
him. But to answer you as you would be understood;
he weeps like a wench that had shed her milk: he
hath confessed himself to Morgan, whom he supposes
to be a friar, from the time of his remembrance to
this very instant disaster of his setting i' the
stocks: and what think you he hath confessed?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Nothing of me, has a'?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
His confession is taken, and it shall be read to his
face: if your lordship be in't, as I believe you
are, you must have the patience to hear it.

p.stage: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
A plague upon him! muffled! he can say nothing of
me: hush, hush!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: Hoodman comes! Portotartarosa

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
He calls for the tortures: what will you say
without 'em?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I will confess what I know without constraint: if
ye pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Bosko chimurcho.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
You are a merciful general. Our general bids you
answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: And truly, as I hope to live.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
'First demand of him how many horse the
duke is strong.' What say you to that?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Five or six thousand; but very weak and
unserviceable: the troops are all scattered, and
the commanders very poor rogues, upon my reputation
and credit and as I hope to live.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Shall I set down your answer so?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Do: I'll take the sacrament on't, how and which way you will.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: All's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
You're deceived, my lord: this is Monsieur
Parolles, the gallant militarist,—that was his own
phrase,—that had the whole theoric of war in the
knot of his scarf, and the practise in the chape of
his dagger.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword
clean. nor believe he can have every thing in him
by wearing his apparel neatly.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Well, that's set down.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Five or six thousand horse, I said,— I will say
true,—or thereabouts, set down, for I'll speak truth.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: He's very near the truth in this.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
But I con him no thanks for't, in the nature he
delivers it.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Poor rogues, I pray you, say.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Well, that's set down.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I humbly thank you, sir: a truth's a truth, the
rogues are marvellous poor.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
'Demand of him, of what strength they are
a-foot.' What say you to that?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present
hour, I will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a
hundred and fifty; Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so
many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick,
and Gratii, two hundred and fifty each; mine own
company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred and
fifty each: so that the muster-file, rotten and
sound, upon my life, amounts not to fifteen thousand
poll; half of the which dare not shake snow from off
their cassocks, lest they shake themselves to pieces.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: What shall be done to him?

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my
condition, and what credit I have with the duke.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Well, that's set down.

'You shall demand of him, whether one Captain Dumain
be i' the camp, a Frenchman; what his reputation is
with the duke; what his valour, honesty, and
expertness in wars; or whether he thinks it were not
possible, with well-weighing sums of gold, to
corrupt him to revolt.' What say you to this? what
do you know of it?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I beseech you, let me answer to the particular of
the inter'gatories: demand them singly.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Do you know this Captain Dumain?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I know him: a' was a botcher's 'prentice in Paris,
from whence he was whipped for getting the shrieve's
fool with child,—a dumb innocent, that could not
say him nay.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know
his brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Well, is this captain in the duke of Florence's camp?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
Nay look not so upon me; we shall hear of your
lordship anon.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: What is his reputation with the duke?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
The duke knows him for no other but a poor officer
of mine; and writ to me this other day to turn him
out o' the band: I think I have his letter in my pocket.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Marry, we'll search.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
In good sadness, I do not know; either it is there,
or it is upon a file with the duke's other letters
in my tent.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Here 'tis; here's a paper: shall I read it to you?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: I do not know if it be it or no.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Our interpreter does it well.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: Excellently.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: 'Dian, the count's a fool, and full of gold,'—

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
That is not the duke's letter, sir; that is an
advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one
Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one Count
Rousillon, a foolish idle boy, but for all that very
ruttish: I pray you, sir, put it up again.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: Nay, I'll read it first, by your favour.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in the
behalf of the maid; for I knew the young count to be
a dangerous and lascivious boy, who is a whale to
virginity and devours up all the fry it finds.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Damnable both-sides rogue!

sp.speaker: First Soldier
BERTRAM
sp.p:
He shall be whipped through the army with this rhyme
in's forehead.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold
linguist and the armipotent soldier.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
I could endure any thing before but a cat, and now
he's a cat to me.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
I perceive, sir, by the general's looks, we shall be
fain to hang you.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
My life, sir, in any case: not that I am afraid to
die; but that, my offences being many, I would
repent out the remainder of nature: let me live,
sir, in a dungeon, i' the stocks, or any where, so I may live.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
We'll see what may be done, so you confess freely;
therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain: you
have answered to his reputation with the duke and to
his valour: what is his honesty?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister: for
rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus: he
professes not keeping of oaths; in breaking 'em he
is stronger than Hercules: he will lie, sir, with
such volubility, that you would think truth were a
fool: drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will
be swine-drunk; and in his sleep he does little
harm, save to his bed-clothes about him; but they
know his conditions and lay him in straw. I have but
little more to say, sir, of his honesty: he has
every thing that an honest man should not have; what
an honest man should have, he has nothing.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: I begin to love him for this.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon
him for me, he's more and more a cat.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: What say you to his expertness in war?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Faith, sir, he has led the drum before the English
tragedians; to belie him, I will not, and more of
his soldiership I know not; except, in that country
he had the honour to be the officer at a place there
called Mile-end, to instruct for the doubling of
files: I would do the man what honour I can, but of
this I am not certain.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
He hath out-villained villany so far, that the
rarity redeems him.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: A pox on him, he's a cat still.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
His qualities being at this poor price, I need not
to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Sir, for a quart d'ecu he will sell the fee-simple
of his salvation, the inheritance of it; and cut the
entail from all remainders, and a perpetual
succession for it perpetually.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain?

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: Why does be ask him of me?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
E'en a crow o' the same nest; not altogether so
great as the first in goodness, but greater a great
deal in evil: he excels his brother for a coward,
yet his brother is reputed one of the best that is:
in a retreat he outruns any lackey; marry, in coming
on he has the cramp.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray
the Florentine?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Rousillon.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p: I'll whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
I'll no more drumming; a plague of all
drums! Only to seem to deserve well, and to
beguile the supposition of that lascivious young boy
the count, have I run into this danger. Yet who
would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
There is no remedy, sir, but you must die: the
general says, you that have so traitorously
discovered the secrets of your army and made such
pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can
serve the world for no honest use; therefore you
must die. Come, headsman, off with his head.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: That shall you, and take your leave of all your friends.
So, look about you: know you any here?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Good morrow, noble captain.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p: God save you, noble captain.

sp.speaker: Second Lord
sp.p:
Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu?
I am for France.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.p:
Good captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet
you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rousillon?
an I were not a very coward, I'ld compel it of you:
but fare you well.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
You are undone, captain, all but your scarf; that
has a knot on't yet

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.p:
If you could find out a country where but women were
that had received so much shame, you might begin an
impudent nation. Fare ye well, sir; I am for France
too: we shall speak of you there.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Yet am I thankful: if my heart were great,
'Twould burst at this. Captain I'll be no more;
But I will eat and drink, and sleep as soft
As captain shall: simply the thing I am
Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart,
Let him fear this, for it will come to pass
that every braggart shall be found an ass.
Rust, sword? cool, blushes! and, Parolles, live
Safest in shame! being fool'd, by foolery thrive!
There's place and means for every man alive.
I'll after them.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you,
One of the greatest in the Christian world
Shall be my surety; 'fore whose throne 'tis needful,
Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel:
Time was, I did him a desired office,
Dear almost as his life; which gratitude
Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth,
And answer, thanks: I duly am inform'd
His grace is at Marseilles; to which place
We have convenient convoy. You must know
I am supposed dead: the army breaking,
My husband hies him home; where, heaven aiding,
And by the leave of my good lord the king,
We'll be before our welcome.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
Gentle madam,
You never had a servant to whose trust
Your business was more welcome.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
Nor you, mistress,
Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour
To recompense your love: doubt not but heaven
Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motive
And helper to a husband. But, O strange men!
That can such sweet use make of what they hate,
When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts
Defiles the pitchy night: so lust doth play
With what it loathes for that which is away.
But more of this hereafter. You, Diana,
Under my poor instructions yet must suffer
Something in my behalf.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
Let death and honesty
Go with your impositions, I am yours
Upon your will to suffer.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
Yet, I pray you:
But with the word the time will bring on summer,
When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns,
And be as sweet as sharp. We must away;
Our wagon is prepared, and time revives us:
All's well that ends well; still the fine's the crown;
Whate'er the course, the end is the renown.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipt-taffeta
fellow there, whose villanous saffron would have
made all the unbaked and doughy youth of a nation in
his colour: your daughter-in-law had been alive at
this hour, and your son here at home, more advanced
by the king than by that red-tailed humble-bee I speak of.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
I would I had not known him; it was the death of the
most virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had
praise for creating. If she had partaken of my
flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a mother, I
could not have owed her a more rooted love.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
'Twas a good lady, 'twas a good lady: we may pick a
thousand salads ere we light on such another herb.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Indeed, sir, she was the sweet marjoram of the
salad, or rather, the herb of grace.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: They are not herbs, you knave; they are nose-herbs.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir; I have not much
skill in grass.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: Whether dost thou profess thyself, a knave or a fool?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a man's.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: Your distinction?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I would cozen the man of his wife and do his service.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: So you were a knave at his service, indeed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave and fool.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: At your service.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as
great a prince as you are.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: Who's that? a Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Faith, sir, a' has an English name; but his fisnomy
is more hotter in France than there.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: What prince is that?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
The black prince, sir; alias, the prince of
darkness; alias, the devil.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
Clown
sp.p:
I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved a
great fire; and the master I speak of ever keeps a
good fire. But, sure, he is the prince of the
world; let his nobility remain in's court. I am for
the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be
too little for pomp to enter: some that humble
themselves may; but the many will be too chill and
tender, and they'll be for the flowery way that
leads to the broad gate and the great fire.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
Go thy ways, I begin to be aweary of thee; and I
tell thee so before, because I would not fall out
with thee. Go thy ways: let my horses be well
looked to, without any tricks.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
If I put any tricks upon 'em, sir, they shall be
jades' tricks; which are their own right by the law of nature.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: A shrewd knave and an unhappy.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
So he is. My lord that's gone made himself much
sport out of him: by his authority he remains here,
which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness; and,
indeed, he has no pace, but runs where he will.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
I like him well; 'tis not amiss. And I was about to
tell you, since I heard of the good lady's death and
that my lord your son was upon his return home, I
moved the king my master to speak in the behalf of
my daughter; which, in the minority of them both,
his majesty, out of a self-gracious remembrance, did
first propose: his highness hath promised me to do
it: and, to stop up the displeasure he hath
conceived against your son, there is no fitter
matter. How does your ladyship like it?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
With very much content, my lord; and I wish it
happily effected.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
His highness comes post from Marseilles, of as able
body as when he numbered thirty: he will be here
to-morrow, or I am deceived by him that in such
intelligence hath seldom failed.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
It rejoices me, that I hope I shall see him ere I
die. I have letters that my son will be here
to-night: I shall beseech your lordship to remain
with me till they meet together.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might
safely be admitted.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: You need but plead your honourable privilege.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but I
thank my God it holds yet.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
O madam, yonder's my lord your son with a patch of
velvet on's face: whether there be a scar under't
or no, the velvet knows; but 'tis a goodly patch of
velvet: his left cheek is a cheek of two pile and a
half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good livery
of honour; so belike is that.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: But it is your carbonadoed face.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
Let us go see your son, I pray you: I long to talk
with the young noble soldier.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Faith there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate fine
hats and most courteous feathers, which bow the head
and nod at every man.

p.stage: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
But this exceeding posting day and night
Must wear your spirits low; we cannot help it:
But since you have made the days and nights as one,
To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs,
Be bold you do so grow in my requital
As nothing can unroot you. In happy time;

This man may help me to his majesty's ear,
If he would spend his power. God save you, sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: And you.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Sir, I have seen you in the court of France.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: I have been sometimes there.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
I do presume, sir, that you are not fallen
From the report that goes upon your goodness;
An therefore, goaded with most sharp occasions,
Which lay nice manners by, I put you to
The use of your own virtues, for the which
I shall continue thankful.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: What's your will?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
That it will please you
To give this poor petition to the king,
And aid me with that store of power you have
To come into his presence.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: The king's not here.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Not here, sir!

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p:
Not, indeed:
He hence removed last night and with more haste
Than is his use.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Lord, how we lose our pains!

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
ALL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL yet,
Though time seem so adverse and means unfit.
I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p:
Marry, as I take it, to Rousillon;
Whither I am going.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
I do beseech you, sir,
Since you are like to see the king before me,
Commend the paper to his gracious hand,
Which I presume shall render you no blame
But rather make you thank your pains for it.
I will come after you with what good speed
Our means will make us means.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: This I'll do for you.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
And you shall find yourself to be well thank'd,
Whate'er falls more. We must to horse again.
Go, go, provide.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Good Monsieur Lavache, give my Lord Lafeu this
letter: I have ere now, sir, been better known to
you, when I have held familiarity with fresher
clothes; but I am now, sir, muddied in fortune's
mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong
displeasure.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Truly, fortune's displeasure is but sluttish, if it
smell so strongly as thou speakest of: I will
henceforth eat no fish of fortune's buttering.
Prithee, allow the wind.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir; I spake
but by a metaphor.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop my
nose; or against any man's metaphor. Prithee, get
thee further.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Foh! prithee, stand away: a paper from fortune's
close-stool to give to a nobleman! Look, here he
comes himself.

Here is a purr of fortune's, sir, or of fortune's
cat,—but not a musk-cat,—that has fallen into the
unclean fishpond of her displeasure, and, as he
says, is muddied withal: pray you, sir, use the
carp as you may; for he looks like a poor, decayed,
ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I do pity his
distress in my similes of comfort and leave him to
your lordship.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
My lord, I am a man whom fortune hath cruelly
scratched.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
And what would you have me to do? 'Tis too late to
pare her nails now. Wherein have you played the
knave with fortune, that she should scratch you, who
of herself is a good lady and would not have knaves
thrive long under her? There's a quart d'ecu for
you: let the justices make you and fortune friends:
I am for other business.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: I beseech your honour to hear me one single word.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
You beg a single penny more: come, you shall ha't;
save your word.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: My name, my good lord, is Parolles.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
You beg more than 'word,' then. Cox my passion!
give me your hand. How does your drum?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: O my good lord, you were the first that found me!

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: Was I, in sooth? and I was the first that lost thee.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace,
for you did bring me out.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
Out upon thee, knave! dost thou put upon me at once
both the office of God and the devil? One brings
thee in grace and the other brings thee out.

The king's coming; I know by his trumpets. Sirrah,
inquire further after me; I had talk of you last
night: though you are a fool and a knave, you shall
eat; go to, follow.

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: I praise God for you.

p.stage: Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
We lost a jewel of her; and our esteem
Was made much poorer by it: but your son,
As mad in folly, lack'd the sense to know
Her estimation home.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
KING
sp.p:
My honour'd lady,
I have forgiven and forgotten all;
Though my revenges were high bent upon him,
And watch'd the time to shoot.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
This I must say,
But first I beg my pardon, the young lord
Did to his majesty, his mother and his lady
Offence of mighty note; but to himself
The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife
Whose beauty did astonish the survey
Of richest eyes, whose words all ears took captive,
Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn'd to serve
Humbly call'd mistress.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Praising what is lost
Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither;
We are reconciled, and the first view shall kill
All repetition: let him not ask our pardon;
The nature of his great offence is dead,
And deeper than oblivion we do bury
The incensing relics of it: let him approach,
A stranger, no offender; and inform him
So 'tis our will he should.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: I shall, my liege.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What says he to your daughter? have you spoke?

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: All that he is hath reference to your highness.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent me
That set him high in fame.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: He looks well on't.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
I am not a day of season,
For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail
In me at once: but to the brightest beams
Distracted clouds give way; so stand thou forth;
The time is fair again.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
My high-repented blames,
Dear sovereign, pardon to me.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
All is whole;
Not one word more of the consumed time.
Let's take the instant by the forward top;
For we are old, and on our quick'st decrees
The inaudible and noiseless foot of Time
Steals ere we can effect them. You remember
The daughter of this lord?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
Admiringly, my liege, at first
I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart
Durst make too bold a herald of my tongue
Where the impression of mine eye infixing,
Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me,
Which warp'd the line of every other favour;
Scorn'd a fair colour, or express'd it stolen;
Extended or contracted all proportions
To a most hideous object: thence it came
That she whom all men praised and whom myself,
Since I have lost, have loved, was in mine eye
The dust that did offend it.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Well excused:
That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away
From the great compt: but love that comes too late,
Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried,
To the great sender turns a sour offence,
Crying, 'That's good that's gone.' Our rash faults
Make trivial price of serious things we have,
Not knowing them until we know their grave:
Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust,
Destroy our friends and after weep their dust
Our own love waking cries to see what's done,
While shame full late sleeps out the afternoon.
Be this sweet Helen's knell, and now forget her.
Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin:
The main consents are had; and here we'll stay
To see our widower's second marriage-day.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Which better than the first, O dear heaven, bless!
Or, ere they meet, in me, O nature, cesse!

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
Come on, my son, in whom my house's name
Must be digested, give a favour from you
To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter,
That she may quickly come.

By my old beard,
And every hair that's on't, Helen, that's dead,
Was a sweet creature: such a ring as this,
The last that e'er I took her at court,
I saw upon her finger.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: Hers it was not.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Now, pray you, let me see it; for mine eye,
While I was speaking, oft was fasten'd to't.
This ring was mine; and, when I gave it Helen,
I bade her, if her fortunes ever stood
Necessitied to help, that by this token
I would relieve her. Had you that craft, to reave
her
Of what should stead her most?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
My gracious sovereign,
Howe'er it pleases you to take it so,
The ring was never hers.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
Son, on my life,
I have seen her wear it; and she reckon'd it
At her life's rate.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: I am sure I saw her wear it.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
You are deceived, my lord; she never saw it:
In Florence was it from a casement thrown me,
Wrapp'd in a paper, which contain'd the name
Of her that threw it: noble she was, and thought
I stood engaged: but when I had subscribed
To mine own fortune and inform'd her fully
I could not answer in that course of honour
As she had made the overture, she ceased
In heavy satisfaction and would never
Receive the ring again.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Plutus himself,
That knows the tinct and multiplying medicine,
Hath not in nature's mystery more science
Than I have in this ring: 'twas mine, 'twas Helen's,
Whoever gave it you. Then, if you know
That you are well acquainted with yourself,
Confess 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement
You got it from her: she call'd the saints to surety
That she would never put it from her finger,
Unless she gave it to yourself in bed,
Where you have never come, or sent it us
Upon her great disaster.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: She never saw it.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Thou speak'st it falsely, as I love mine honour;
And makest conjectural fears to come into me
Which I would fain shut out. If it should prove
That thou art so inhuman,—'twill not prove so;—
And yet I know not: thou didst hate her deadly,
And she is dead; which nothing, but to close
Her eyes myself, could win me to believe,
More than to see this ring. Take him away.

My fore-past proofs, howe'er the matter fall,
Shall tax my fears of little vanity,
Having vainly fear'd too little. Away with him!
We'll sift this matter further.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
If you shall prove
This ring was ever hers, you shall as easy
Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence,
Where yet she never was.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: I am wrapp'd in dismal thinkings.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p:
Gracious sovereign,
Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not:
Here's a petition from a Florentine,
Who hath for four or five removes come short
To tender it herself. I undertook it,
Vanquish'd thereto by the fair grace and speech
Of the poor suppliant, who by this I know
Is here attending: her business looks in her
With an importing visage; and she told me,
In a sweet verbal brief, it did concern
Your highness with herself.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Upon his many protestations to marry me
when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won
me. Now is the Count Rousillon a widower: his vows
are forfeited to me, and my honour's paid to him. He
stole from Florence, taking no leave, and I follow
him to his country for justice: grant it me, O
king! in you it best lies; otherwise a seducer
flourishes, and a poor maid is undone.
DIANA CAPILET.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll for
this: I'll none of him.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
The heavens have thought well on thee Lafeu,
To bring forth this discovery. Seek these suitors:
Go speedily and bring again the count.
I am afeard the life of Helen, lady,
Was foully snatch'd.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p: Now, justice on the doers!

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you,
And that you fly them as you swear them lordship,
Yet you desire to marry.
What woman's that?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine,
Derived from the ancient Capilet:
My suit, as I do understand, you know,
And therefore know how far I may be pitied.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
I am her mother, sir, whose age and honour
Both suffer under this complaint we bring,
And both shall cease, without your remedy.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Come hither, count; do you know these women?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
My lord, I neither can nor will deny
But that I know them: do they charge me further?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: Why do you look so strange upon your wife?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: She's none of mine, my lord.

sp.speaker: DIANA
LAFEU
sp.p:
Your reputation comes too short for my daughter; you
are no husband for her.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
My lord, this is a fond and desperate creature,
Whom sometime I have laugh'd with: let your highness
Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour
Than for to think that I would sink it here.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Sir, for my thoughts, you have them ill to friend
Till your deeds gain them: fairer prove your honour
Than in my thought it lies.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
Good my lord,
Ask him upon his oath, if he does think
He had not my virginity.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What say'st thou to her?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
She's impudent, my lord,
And was a common gamester to the camp.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
He does me wrong, my lord; if I were so,
He might have bought me at a common price:
Do not believe him. O, behold this ring,
Whose high respect and rich validity
Did lack a parallel; yet for all that
He gave it to a commoner o' the camp,
If I be one.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.p:
He blushes, and 'tis it:
Of six preceding ancestors, that gem,
Conferr'd by testament to the sequent issue,
Hath it been owed and worn. This is his wife;
That ring's a thousand proofs.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Methought you said
You saw one here in court could witness it.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
I did, my lord, but loath am to produce
So bad an instrument: his name's Parolles.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: I saw the man to-day, if man he be.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Find him, and bring him hither.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
What of him?
He's quoted for a most perfidious slave,
With all the spots o' the world tax'd and debosh'd;
Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth.
Am I or that or this for what he'll utter,
That will speak any thing?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: She hath that ring of yours.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
I think she has: certain it is I liked her,
And boarded her i' the wanton way of youth:
She knew her distance and did angle for me,
Madding my eagerness with her restraint,
As all impediments in fancy's course
Are motives of more fancy; and, in fine,
Her infinite cunning, with her modern grace,
Subdued me to her rate: she got the ring;
And I had that which any inferior might
At market-price have bought.

sp.speaker: DIANA
BERTRAM
sp.p: I have it not.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: What ring was yours, I pray you?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p:
Sir, much like
The same upon your finger.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Know you this ring? this ring was his of late.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: And this was it I gave him, being abed.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
The story then goes false, you threw it him
Out of a casement.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: I have spoke the truth.

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p: My lord, I do confess the ring was hers.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
You boggle shrewdly, every feather stars you.
Is this the man you speak of?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Tell me, sirrah, but tell me true, I charge you,
Not fearing the displeasure of your master,
Which on your just proceeding I'll keep off,
By him and by this woman here what know you?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
So please your majesty, my master hath been an
honourable gentleman: tricks he hath had in him,
which gentlemen have.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Come, come, to the purpose: did he love this woman?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Faith, sir, he did love her; but how?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: How, I pray you?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: He loved her, sir, and loved her not.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
As thou art a knave, and no knave. What an
equivocal companion is this!

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: I am a poor man, and at your majesty's command.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: He's a good drum, my lord, but a naughty orator.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: Do you know he promised me marriage?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p: Faith, I know more than I'll speak.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: But wilt thou not speak all thou knowest?

sp.speaker: PAROLLES
sp.p:
Yes, so please your majesty. I did go between them,
as I said; but more than that, he loved her: for
indeed he was mad for her, and talked of Satan and
of Limbo and of Furies and I know not what: yet I
was in that credit with them at that time that I
knew of their going to bed, and of other motions,
as promising her marriage, and things which would
derive me ill will to speak of; therefore I will not
speak what I know.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst say
they are married: but thou art too fine in thy
evidence; therefore stand aside.
This ring, you say, was yours?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Where did you buy it? or who gave it you?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Who lent it you?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: It was not lent me neither.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Where did you find it, then?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: I found it not.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
If it were yours by none of all these ways,
How could you give it him?

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: I never gave it him.

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p:
This woman's an easy glove, my lord; she goes off
and on at pleasure.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: This ring was mine; I gave it his first wife.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: It might be yours or hers, for aught I know.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Take her away; I do not like her now;
To prison with her: and away with him.
Unless thou tell'st me where thou hadst this ring,
Thou diest within this hour.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: I'll never tell you.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Take her away.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: I'll put in bail, my liege.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: I think thee now some common customer.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: By Jove, if ever I knew man, 'twas you.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Wherefore hast thou accused him all this while?

sp.speaker: DIANA
KING
sp.p: She does abuse our ears: to prison with her.

sp.speaker: DIANA
sp.p: Good mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir:

The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for,
And he shall surety me. But for this lord,
Who hath abused me, as he knows himself,
Though yet he never harm'd me, here I quit him:
He knows himself my bed he hath defiled;
And at that time he got his wife with child:
Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick:
So there's my riddle: one that's dead is quick:
And now behold the meaning.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Is there no exorcist
Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes?
Is't real that I see?

sp.speaker: HELENA
BERTRAM
sp.p: Both, both. O, pardon!

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
O my good lord, when I was like this maid,
I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring;
And, look you, here's your letter; this it says:
'When from my finger you can get this ring
And are by me with child,' &c. This is done:
Will you be mine, now you are doubly won?

sp.speaker: BERTRAM
sp.p:
If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly,
I'll love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p:
If it appear not plain and prove untrue,
Deadly divorce step between me and you!
O my dear mother, do I see you living?

sp.speaker: LAFEU
sp.p: Mine eyes smell onions; I shall weep anon:

Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher: so,
I thank thee: wait on me home, I'll make sport with thee:
Let thy courtesies alone, they are scurvy ones.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Let us from point to point this story know,
To make the even truth in pleasure flow.

If thou be'st yet a fresh uncropped flower,
Choose thou thy husband, and I'll pay thy dower;
For I can guess that by thy honest aid
Thou keep'st a wife herself, thyself a maid.
Of that and all the progress, more or less,
Resolvedly more leisure shall express:
All yet seems well; and if it end so meet,
The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
The king's a beggar, now the play is done:
All is well ended, if this suit be won,
That you express content; which we will pay,
With strife to please you, day exceeding day:
Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts;
Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.
